senses.de: Feeling anxious or scared, often because of something that might happen
senses.ex: She felt very nervous before her exam.

Tips.title: Expectation Anxiety
Tips.description: Used when fear of the unknown or future events causes anxiety.
Tips.example: I'm nervous about the results; they could change everything.

Tips.title: Emotion Intensity
Tips.description: The degree varies from slight unease to intense fear.
Tips.example: She was a bit nervous meeting his parents, but it went well.

Tips.title: Non-Medical Use
Tips.description: Commonly used in everyday situations, not related to medical conditions.
Tips.example: Jack gets nervous before every football match.

senses.ex: You must be patient with him. He's a nervous type.

Tips.title: Personality Trait
Tips.description: Describes someone inclined to anxiety, often generally, not just in one situation.
Tips.example: Mara is nervous by nature and worries over small things.

Tips.title: Composure Absence
Tips.description: Implies a lack of calmness or composure in one's manner.
Tips.example: He answered with a nervous laugh, avoiding eye contact.

Tips.title: Body Language Cues
Tips.description: Physical signs, like fidgeting or sweating, can show nervousness.
Tips.example: Her nervous fidgeting betrayed her confident tone.

senses.de: Related to the nerves or nervous system
senses.ex: He's suffering from a nervous disorder.

Tips.title: Medical Context
Tips.description: Used in discussions about health, specifically regarding the nervous system.
Tips.example: After the accident, she developed a nervous twitch.

Tips.title: Technical Language
Tips.description: Often found in medical or scholarly texts, not in casual conversation.
Tips.example: The neurologist specializes in nervous system pathologies.

Tips.title: Biology Classes
Tips.description: Might be used when learning about human anatomy and physiology.
Tips.example: During biology class, we studied the central nervous system.

senses.de: Showing skill or sensitivity in dealing with people or difficult issues
senses.ex: A nervous negotiation with the kidnappers

Tips.title: Delicate Handling
Tips.description: Refers to careful, considerate management of tricky situations.
Tips.example: The peace talks required nervous diplomacy.

Tips.title: Skilled Performance
Tips.description: Indicates performing tasks with exceptional awareness and precision.
Tips.example: The bomb technician’s nervous handwork saved lives.

Anxious.wordDefinition:
Anxious and nervous are two similar words, but they are used in slightly different situations.

Anxious generally describes a feeling of worry or unease about something that might happen in the future. For example, a student might feel anxious about an upcoming exam.

Anxious describes a general feeling of worry about something that hasn't happened yet, while nervous describes a specific feeling of unease in the present or near future.

Apprehensive.wordDefinition:
Apprehensive means feeling worried or uneasy about something that may happen in the future, while nervous means feeling uneasy or anxious about something that is happening right now.

For example, someone might feel apprehensive about an upcoming exam because they are worried about how they will do. On the other hand, they might feel nervous during the exam because of the pressure they are feeling in that moment.

Apprehensive is more about future events that haven't happened yet, while nervous is more about present situations that are causing anxiety or unease.

Edgy.wordDefinition:
Edgy means that someone is on the verge of being irritated or impatient, often with tension or anxiety. This is typically used when someone is "on edge" or easily agitated.

Edgy describes a person who is easily agitated, while nervous describes a person who is feeling anxious or worried.

Fidgety.wordDefinition:
Fidgety refers to the need to move around and the inability to sit or stand still.

It is used when someone feels anxious or apprehensive. Fidgety is applicable when someone is physically restless, while nervous is applicable when someone is emotionally unsettled.

Jittery.wordDefinition:
Both jittery and nervous refer to a feeling of anxiety or unease. Jittery usually means someone who is visibly restless and twitchy, while nervous typically refers to more of an emotional state of anxiety or fear.

For example, if someone is jittery, they might shake or fidget and seem unable to sit still. If someone is nervous, they might feel a knot in their stomach or be worried about something specific, like a test or a job interview.

Perturb.wordDefinition:
Perturb means to disturb or unsettle someone, often to a greater extent than simply feeling nervous. It implies a more significant disruption or disturbance to one's emotional state, and can refer to a broader range of circumstances, such as being disturbed by a loud noise or upset by a traumatic event.

Nervous is a mild form of feeling uneasy, while perturb is a stronger state of being unsettled or disturbed.

Restless.wordDefinition:
Restless is used when you feel unsettled or agitated, but you may not necessarily know the reason behind it.

It's like having a lot of energy but not knowing what to do with it. For example, you could feel restless when you're stuck at home on a rainy day and don't have anything to do.

So, nervousness is usually linked to a specific situation or object, whereas restlessness is more general and could stem from boredom, excitement, or just having excess energy.

Tense.wordDefinition:
Nervous and tense both describe feelings of discomfort or anxiety, but there are slight differences in their meanings.

Tense, on the other hand, describes a physical state of tightness or rigidity that can come from stress or anxiety. You might feel tense in your muscles when you're worried, especially in places like your shoulders, neck, or jaw.

Nervous refers more to an emotional or mental state, while tense refers more to a physical state.

Uneasy.wordDefinition:
Nervous and uneasy both describe a feeling of discomfort and apprehension.

For example, a person might feel nervous before a job interview or a big test. Uneasy, on the other hand, is a more general feeling of discomfort, often related to a sense of unease or uncertainty about a particular situation or circumstance.

For example, a person might feel uneasy in a new social setting or when confronting a difficult choice. Nervous is more specific and related to anxiety or fear, while uneasy is more general and related to discomfort or uncertainty.

quotes.Text: I'm humble 'cause I think many years ago people say, 'Well, Alibaba's terrible company'. And I know we were not that terrible. We're pretty good; we're better than people thought. But today, when people have a high expectation on you, and I start to worry and nervous because we are not good yet.
quotes.Title: Chinese Businessman
quotes.Name: Jack Ma

quotes.Text: I get so nervous on stage I can't help but talk. I try. I try telling my brain: stop sending words to the mouth. But I get nervous and turn into my grandma. Behind the eyes it's pure fear. I find it difficult to believe I'm going to be able to deliver.
quotes.Title: English Singer
quotes.Name: Adele

quotes.Text: Guys usually like a very natural look. I think it's bad idea to wear a strong lip on a first date - or for the first few dates. I'm always too nervous he'll kiss it off - if I'm lucky enough to get a kiss! I also think soft, sexy hair is important.
quotes.Title: American Actress
quotes.Name: Emmy Rossum

quotes.Text: They gave their money, and they gave their screams. But the Beatles kind of gave their nervous systems. They used us as an excuse to go mad, the world did, and then blamed it on us.
quotes.Title: British Musician
quotes.Name: George Harrison

quotes.Text: When I got to match point in the final I was afraid I'd be a little nervous, but I just said, You have to stay focused, just think about what you have to do.
quotes.Title: Argentinian Athlete
quotes.Name: Gabriela Sabatini

quotes.Text: In my everyday life I'm a little bit nervous and not particularly brave. I feel like if I can be completely brave in my work then I'm doing something right.
quotes.Title: Australian Actress
quotes.Name: Emily Browning

quotes.Text: Anyone who tells you they're not nervous playing on the CMAs stage, I'm afraid they're not telling you the whole story.
quotes.Title: American Musician
quotes.Name: Hunter Hayes

quotes.Text: I very rarely get nervous as an actor. Very rarely.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Corin Nemec

quotes.Text: I have the most nervous stomach in the world.
quotes.Title: American Actor
quotes.Name: Sean Hayes

quotes.Text: I get nervous if the bath is too deep.
quotes.Title: British Journalist
quotes.Name: Andrew Neil
